events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This is a new alert.
Issued 1 May 2024 1:32 PM.
Cyclone Red Alert for DENHAM in PILBARA

A Red Alert is current for people in or near DENHAM due to TC Deana. There is a threat to lives and homes. You are in danger and need to act immediately.

WHAT TO DO

  • Shelter indoors now. It is too late to leave.

  • Stay in the strongest, safest part of the building.

  • Stay away from doors and windows, and keep them closed.

  • Keep your emergency kit with you.

  • Stay indoors until the ALL CLEAR is given by authorities.

  • THIS IS A NEW MESSAGE THAT I HAVE PUT IN FOR TESTING

Cyclone Yellow Alert for CORAL BAY to SHARK BAY in PILBARA region

A Yellow Alert is current for people in or near CORAL BAY to SHARK BAY due to Tropical Cyclone Deana. There is a possible threat to lives and homes as a cyclone is approaching the area. You need to take action and get ready to shelter from a cyclone.

  • Tropical Cyclone Deana is expected to result in a significant storm surge along parts of the Pilbara including Exmouth to Onslow.

  • There is a risk that properties could become inundated in (location) within 48 hours/at (time).

  • To view a map of potential inundation areas right click here and open in a new tab. To view on a mobile device press and hold the link for 5 seconds.

  • If you live in the risk area, you need to start preparing now to relocate to a safer place.

  • This could be with family or friends who live away from the area, or at a local evacuation centre.

  • Move furniture and other items up high to prevent water damage. Store or tie-down loose items which may be moved by strong winds.

  • Prepare an evacuation kit including medicines, clothing, important documents and pet supplies.

  • Consider your evacuation route to make sure it will be accessible.

WHAT TO DO

  • Put your cyclone plan into action and go to your nearest evacuation centre or safer place.
  • Keep your emergency kit with you.
  • Move vehicles under cover.
  • Fasten cyclone screens, board up or heavily tape exposed windows.
  • Ensure pets and animals are in a safe area.
  • Be aware that shops may now be closing.
Cyclone Blue Alert for ONSLOW to EXMOUTH in the PILBARA region

A BLUE ALERT is current for people in or near ONSLOW due to Tropical Cyclone Deana. Although there is no immediate danger you need to start preparing for dangerous weather and keep up to date.

  • (details eg: BoM cyclone name / a tropical low) will result in a significant storm surge along parts of the (coast) including (details eg: areas / areas that are bounded by).
  • There is a risk that properties could become inundated in (location) (details eg: within 24 hours / at specific time).
  • To view a map of potential inundation areas right click here and open in a new tab. To view on a mobile device press and hold the link for 5 seconds.
  • If you live in the risk area, you need to relocate now to a safer place.
  • This could be with family or friends who live away from the area, or at a local evacuation centre.
  • Take your evacuation kit including medicines, clothing, important documents and pet supplies.
  • Lock up your house and buildings.
  • If there is a life-threatening situation call 000.
  • Register with Register.Find.Reunite.

WHAT TO DO

  • Get ready for dangerous weather by preparing your home inside and out.

  • Secure boats, caravans, trailers, garden sheds, outdoor furniture, rainwater tanks, LPG bottles, loose material and rubbish around your home and workplace.

  • Ensure your emergency kit is complete and check your family knows what to do.

  • Check in with friends and neighbours to make sure they’re preparing too.

The safest route for the BLUE area is the following X X and X

Cyclone All Clear for DENHAM in PILBARA

An ALL CLEAR advice is current for people in or near DENHAM due to Tropical Cyclone Deana. The cyclone is now weakening. The threat has passed but take care to avoid the dangers caused by damage.

The Shire of Denham is assisting people get back on their feet by (details eg: include a description of the recovery activities they are doing).

WHAT TO DO

  • It is now safe to return home.
  • If returning, take care on the roads, obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Drive slowly and be aware of emergency services personnel who are still working in the area.
  • Be careful of fallen power lines and trees, broken water and sewerage pipes, loose roof sheeting and other material.
  • Do not walk, swim or play in floodwaters as they are dangerous.

If returning to a damaged property

  • Protect your feet with closed shoes.
  • Stack loose material clear of water meters, valves and power lines.
  • Keep electricity and all electrical and gas appliances turned off until checked by a qualified tradesperson.
  • Never use matches, cigarette lighters or naked flames when entering a building as there may be a gas leak.
  • Take photographs for insurance purposes and contact your insurance company.
Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at Carnarvon Hospital

  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at (details eg: address and directions if required).

  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.

  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.

Safest route

If you live in Exmouth leave in a southerly direction towards Carnarvon.

Cyclone

ONSLOW, SHIRE OF ASHBURTON
  • Time reported: 10:00 AM, Thursday, May 2, 2024.
  • Last updated: 10:00 AM, Wednesday, May 1, 2024.
  • Reported near ONSLOW, WESTERN AUSTRALIA, in ONSLOW.
Cyclone details

As at 2pm 1/5/24, the Bureau of Meteorology advised Cyclone Deana was off the Pilbara coast.

For current Bureau of Meteorology Watch and Warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/cyclone.

Road closures

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and emergency services personnel working on site.

A number of roads have been closed including:

  • Ningaloo Coast Road

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.
  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.
What Emergency Services are doing
  • DFES is monitoring the situation.
  • 12 State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers from 15 units are sandbagging areas in dangers of flooding.

DFES is working closely with:

  • Red Cross

(details eg: Rescuing trapped people / Treating injured people / Sheltering those left homeless / Assessing the damage / Controlling any fires / Stabilising essential buildings and structures if necessary / Clearing debris from essential facilities / Restoring lifeline services including water, power, gas, telephones, roads, rail)

Health

A number of hospitals have been damaged including the Deana Hospital. The majority of elective surgery has been cancelled today.

Water

The Water Corporation has advised that parts of (Location) are without water. This includes:

  • Example street

  • Example street

For further details visit www.watercorporation.com.au.

School

The Department of Education has advised a number of schools will remain closed including

  • Deana School

  • Deana School 1

For more information contact your school directly or visit the Department of Education.

ADDITIONAL AGENCY

This is additional information to show in the warning TEST

Support information

Emergency assistance is available for individuals or families to alleviate the personal hardship or distress arising as a direct result of a natural disaster. Contact the Department of Communities for further information OR Call theDisaster Response Hotline on 1800032965 for further information (when activated).

Important numbers

  • For SES assistance call 132 500.
  • In a life threatening situation call 000.
  • For the latest weather information call 1300 659 210 or visit www.bom.gov.au.
  • For information about road conditions and closures contact local Police or Main Roads WA on 138 138.
  • If you are concerned about the location of family and friends in the area call the Red Cross State Inquiry Line on 1800 810 710 (if activated).
  • For advice on damaged asbestos contact your insurance company, local government environmental health office or Department of Health on 9388 4999 or after hours on 9328 0553 (in major incident).
Keep up to date

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.

During a power outage, your home phone, computer or other electronic devices connected to the NBN will not work. Include a battery powered radio in your emergency kit.


The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow unless the situation changes.

events.web-text-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES)


Aaron TFB

Issued: 1 May 2024 11:03 AM

A Total Fire Ban has been revoked for 1 May 2024 for the local government districts listed below:

GREAT SOUTHERN
SHIRE OF DENMARK - all day



At these times you must not:

  • Light, maintain or use a fire in the open air
  • Carry out any activity that could start a fire


This includes:

  • Open fires for the purpose of cooking, camping or outdoor entertainment are not allowed including fire pits and bonfires.
  • Hot work such as metal work, grinding, welding, gas cutting is not allowed in the open air except for business and industry if regulatory conditions are met.
  • Off-road activity using a four-wheel drive, quad bike, motorcycle, bobcat or similar vehicle, except for agricultural purposes or by business and industry if regulatory conditions are met.


If a Harvest and Vehicle Movement Ban has been imposed by your local government, off-road activity for agriculture or business and industry including harvesting is banned. Exceptions are made for essential services.


For a list of activities that can or cannot be carried out during a Total Fire Ban and conditions visit dfes.wa.gov.au/totalfirebans or by telephoning the Total Fire Ban Information Line on 1800 709 355.


You could be fined up to $25,000 or jailed for 12 months or both if you breach a Total Fire Ban.


Current Total Fire Bans are also available by visiting www.emergency.wa.gov.au/#totalfirebans
Local Government Authority boundaries on Emergency WA are indicative only and do not represent the exact gazetted local government boundary.


END
Media Contact: DFES Media and Corporate Communications on 9395 9543.

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This is a new alert. Please note road closures.
Issued 2 May 2024 9:34 AM.
Bushfire Emergency Warning for north western part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK

Bushfire EMERGENCY WARNING is in place for people in area north of South Coast Highway in north western part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK.

  • You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive. There is a threat to lives and homes.
  • The alert level for this fire has been upgraded as (reason).
  • Homes in (streets) will be (under threat) by fire in (number) hours.
  • The fire started near the intersection of Denmark, Western Australia, Australia and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in DENMARK.
  • It is burning towards (landmark).

WHAT TO DO

  • It's too late to leave, leaving now would be deadly.
  • You need to shelter in your home in a room away from the fire front and make sure you can easily escape.
  • You must shelter before the fire arrives, as the extreme heat will kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Close all doors and windows and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.
  • Choose a room with two exits and water such as a kitchen or laundry.
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt.
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from cotton or wool, and strong leather boots.

Travel east along South Coast Highway or north

Bushfire Watch and Act for south western part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK

Bushfire WATCH AND ACT is in place for people in the area bounded by South Coast Highway, Brazier Street, Weedon Hill Road and the coastline in the south western part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK.

  • The alert level for this fire has been upgraded as fire conditions have increased.
  • There is a possible threat to lives and homes as a fire is burning in the area and conditions are changing.
  • The fire started near the intersection of Denmark, Western Australia, Australia and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in DENMARK.
  • It is burning towards (landmark).

WHAT TO DO

  • People south of South Coast Highway should be prepared for likely escalation to Emergency Warning.

  • If you are not prepared or you plan to leave, leave now if the way is clear.

  • If you are well prepared and plan to actively defend your home, make final preparations now.

  • If you plan to stay and actively defend, do not rely on mains water pressure as it may be affected. You need to have access to an independent water supply, and start patrolling your property to put out spot fires.

  • Keep doors and windows closed and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.

  • If you are not at home, do not try to return as conditions in the area could be very dangerous.

Travel east along South Coast Highway

Bushfire Advice for Denmark townsite in DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK

Bushfire ADVICE is in place for people in Denmark townsite in DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK.

  • The alert level for this fire has been upgraded as (reason).
  • Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date in case the situation changes.
  • The fire started near the intersection of Mt Shadforth Road and Peace Street in DENMARK.
  • It is burning towards South Coast Highway.

WHAT TO DO

  • Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.

  • Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.

  • Close all doors and windows, and turn off evaporative air conditioners but keep water running through the system if possible.

  • Read through your bushfire survival plan.

  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation gets worse. You can make a plan by visiting My Bushfire Plan.

If driving:

  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.

  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.

  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions. If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.

  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.

Travel east along South Coast Highway.

Bushfire All Clear for eastern part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK

Bushfire ALL CLEAR is in place for people in the area east of the Denmark River in the eastern part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK.

  • The danger has passed but you need to remain vigilant in case the situation changes.

WHAT TO DO

  • Drive slowly and with caution due to smoke and emergency services personnel working in the area.
Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at Denmark Recreation Centre

  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at Denmark Recreation Centre on Strickland Street.

  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.

  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.

Safest route

Bushfire behaviour
  • The bushfire is moving in a southerly direction at 20 km/h.
  • It is out of control and unpredictable.
  • Burning embers are likely to be blown around your home. Spot fires are starting up to 2000 metres ahead of the fire.
  • Flames are Burning into tree tops.
  • Currently there has been 2378 hectares burnt.
  • This means Homes in Denmark may be threatened by fire.
  • Homes are not designed or constructed to withstand a fire in today's conditions.

Test information about bushfire behaviour

Road closures

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and emergency services personnel working on site.

A number of roads have been closed including:

  • South Coast Highway between Sunrise Road and Strickland Street

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.

  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.

Restricted Access Permits

  • Residents and business owners impacted by the fire can apply for a restricted access permit to enter designated areas for a specific time and purpose.

  • A restricted access permit issuing unit has been established at Shire of Denmark Offices. Please bring along valid identity documents including a driver's licence or passport, and proof of the affected address.

  • Due to the ever changing conditions, the issuing of restricted access permits may temporarily stop and your patience is appreciated.

  • For more information about restricted access permits visit the Restricted Access Permits section of the DFES website or click here

What firefighters are doing
  • Firefighters are actively fighting the fire.
  • 50 Career Fire and Rescue Service firefighters are attending.
  • Firefighters have saved 10 homes in the area.
  • Shire of Denmark are also in attendance.
Drones and aerial support

Never fly a drone, model aircraft or multirotor near bushfires. Doing so poses a major safety risk to firefighting personnel in the air and on the ground, and forces aircraft to be grounded or redirected, hindering firefighting efforts.

Peet soil

Fire will burn for many months

Health

A number of hospitals have been damaged including (hospitals). The majority of elective surgery has been cancelled today.

The Department of Health is warning people to avoid contact with water in (area) rivers and at beaches near stormwater outlets due to contaminants being washed into these waters after yesterday's storm.

Parts of the (river name) River/s are experiencing (details eg: heavy inflows of contaminated stormwater, including a number of sewage overflows).

Recreational activities such as swimming, wading, fishing and canoeing should be avoided in these waterways for at least (details eg: a week).

Power

Western Power has advised parts of (location) are without power. This includes:

  • (details eg: list of streets / areas)

For further details visit www.westernpower.com.au.

Water

The Water Corporation has advised that parts of (Location) are without water. This includes:

  • (details eg: list of streets / areas)

For further details visit www.watercorporation.com.au.

Phone

Telstra has advised landline phones and mobile networks (where) have been (temporarily) disrupted due to (details eg: damage / congestion).

Affected customers should call the faults line on 13 22 03. If you are not a Telstra customer contact your service provider for help.

School

The Department of Education has advised a number of schools will remain closed including (schools). For more information contact your school directly or visit the Department of Education.

Insurance

If you have concerns regarding your insurance coverage contact the Insurance Council of Australia on 1300 728 228. This number is not to be used for claims.

Register.Find.Unite

Register with Register.Find.Reunite to let your family and loved ones know you're OK, where you are located and to enquire about a loved one’s whereabouts. You can register from any computer or mobile device or in person at a temporary evacuation centre.

Animal Welfare

Owners or carers of livestock, pets and companion animals should activate their own animal welfare plan. During a bushfire take advice from Local Government Authorities to protect the lives of your animals while keeping yourself safe.

For more information on actions to take for each bushfire warning level, please see the Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development website.

Park Closures

Park closed in

WA Police

New agency information test

Extra information

  • The incident was reported at (time) on (date).

  • The cause of the incident is unknown/accidental/suspicious or deliberately lit.

People are asked to report any suspicious behaviour to Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

Support information

Emergency assistance is available for individuals or families to alleviate the personal hardship or distress arising as a direct result of a natural disaster. Contact the Department of Communities for further information OR Call the Disaster Line on 1800032965 for further information (when activated).

Important numbers

  • In a life threatening situation call 000.
  • If you are concerned about the location of family and friends in the area call the Red Cross State Inquiry Line on 1800 810 710 (if activated).
Keep up to date

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.

During a power outage, your home phone, computer or other electronic devices connected to the NBN will not work. Include a battery powered radio in your emergency kit.


Updates will be issued every hour unless the situation changes.

  • The fire started near the intersection of Denmark, Western Australia, Australia and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in DENMARK.
  • It is burning towards (landmark).

WHAT TO DO

  • It's too late to leave, leaving now would be deadly.
  • You need to shelter in your home in a room away from the fire front and make sure you can easily escape.
  • You must shelter before the fire arrives, as the extreme heat will kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Close all doors and windows and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.
  • Choose a room with two exits and water such as a kitchen or laundry.
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt.
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from cotton or wool, and strong leather boots.

Travel east along South Coast Highway or north

Bushfire Watch and Act for south western part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK

ALERT LEVEL

Bushfire WATCH AND ACT is in place for people in the area bounded by South Coast Highway, Brazier Street, Weedon Hill Road and the coastline in the south western part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK.

  • The alert level for this fire has been upgraded as fire conditions have increased.
  • There is a possible threat to lives and homes as a fire is burning in the area and conditions are changing.
  • The fire started near the intersection of Denmark, Western Australia, Australia and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in DENMARK.
  • It is burning towards (landmark).

WHAT TO DO

  • People south of South Coast Highway should be prepared for likely escalation to Emergency Warning.

  • If you are not prepared or you plan to leave, leave now if the way is clear.

  • If you are well prepared and plan to actively defend your home, make final preparations now.

  • If you plan to stay and actively defend, do not rely on mains water pressure as it may be affected. You need to have access to an independent water supply, and start patrolling your property to put out spot fires.

  • Keep doors and windows closed and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.

  • If you are not at home, do not try to return as conditions in the area could be very dangerous.

Travel east along South Coast Highway

Bushfire Advice for Denmark townsite in DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK

ALERT LEVEL

Bushfire ADVICE is in place for people in Denmark townsite in DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK.

  • The alert level for this fire has been upgraded as (reason).
  • Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date in case the situation changes.
  • The fire started near the intersection of Mt Shadforth Road and Peace Street in DENMARK.
  • It is burning towards South Coast Highway.

WHAT TO DO

  • Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.

  • Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.

  • Close all doors and windows, and turn off evaporative air conditioners but keep water running through the system if possible.

  • Read through your bushfire survival plan.

  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation gets worse. You can make a plan by visiting My Bushfire Plan.

If driving:

  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.

  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.

  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions. If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.

  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.

Travel east along South Coast Highway.

Bushfire All Clear for eastern part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK

ALERT LEVEL

Bushfire ALL CLEAR is in place for people in the area east of the Denmark River in the eastern part of DENMARK in the SHIRE OF DENMARK.

  • The danger has passed but you need to remain vigilant in case the situation changes.

WHAT TO DO

  • Drive slowly and with caution due to smoke and emergency services personnel working in the area.

EVACUATION CENTRE

Evacuation Centre open at Denmark Recreation Centre

  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at Denmark Recreation Centre on Strickland Street.

  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.

  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.

Safest route

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR

  • The bushfire is moving in a southerly direction at 20 km/h.
  • It is out of control and unpredictable.
  • Burning embers are likely to be blown around your home. Spot fires are starting up to 2000 metres ahead of the fire.
  • Flames are Burning into tree tops.
  • Currently there has been 2378 hectares burnt.
  • This means Homes in Denmark may be threatened by fire.
  • Homes are not designed or constructed to withstand a fire in today's conditions.

Test information about bushfire behaviour

ROAD CLOSURES

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and emergency services personnel working on site.

A number of roads have been closed including:

  • South Coast Highway between Sunrise Road and Strickland Street

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.

  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.

RESTRICTED ACCESS PERMITS

  • Residents and business owners impacted by the fire can apply for a restricted access permit to enter designated areas for a specific time and purpose.

  • A restricted access permit issuing unit has been established at Shire of Denmark Offices. Please bring along valid identity documents including a driver's licence or passport, and proof of the affected address.

  • Due to the ever changing conditions, the issuing of restricted access permits may temporarily stop and your patience is appreciated.

  • For more information about restricted access permits visit the Restricted Access Permits section of the DFES website or click here

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING

  • Firefighters are actively fighting the fire.
  • 50 Career Fire and Rescue Service firefighters are attending.
  • Firefighters have saved 10 homes in the area.
  • Shire of Denmark are also in attendance.

DRONES AND AERIAL SUPPORT

Never fly a drone, model aircraft or multirotor near bushfires. Doing so poses a major safety risk to firefighting personnel in the air and on the ground, and forces aircraft to be grounded or redirected, hindering firefighting efforts.

PEET SOIL

Fire will burn for many months

HEALTH

A number of hospitals have been damaged including (hospitals). The majority of elective surgery has been cancelled today.

The Department of Health is warning people to avoid contact with water in (area) rivers and at beaches near stormwater outlets due to contaminants being washed into these waters after yesterday's storm.

Parts of the (river name) River/s are experiencing (details eg: heavy inflows of contaminated stormwater, including a number of sewage overflows).

Recreational activities such as swimming, wading, fishing and canoeing should be avoided in these waterways for at least (details eg: a week).

POWER

Western Power has advised parts of (location) are without power. This includes:

  • (details eg: list of streets / areas)

For further details visit www.westernpower.com.au.

WATER

The Water Corporation has advised that parts of (Location) are without water. This includes:

  • (details eg: list of streets / areas)

For further details visit www.watercorporation.com.au.

PHONE

Telstra has advised landline phones and mobile networks (where) have been (temporarily) disrupted due to (details eg: damage / congestion).

Affected customers should call the faults line on 13 22 03. If you are not a Telstra customer contact your service provider for help.

SCHOOL

The Department of Education has advised a number of schools will remain closed including (schools). For more information contact your school directly or visit the Department of Education.

INSURANCE

If you have concerns regarding your insurance coverage contact the Insurance Council of Australia on 1300 728 228. This number is not to be used for claims.

REGISTER.FIND.UNITE

Register with Register.Find.Reunite to let your family and loved ones know you're OK, where you are located and to enquire about a loved one’s whereabouts. You can register from any computer or mobile device or in person at a temporary evacuation centre.

ANIMAL WELFARE

Owners or carers of livestock, pets and companion animals should activate their own animal welfare plan. During a bushfire take advice from Local Government Authorities to protect the lives of your animals while keeping yourself safe.

For more information on actions to take for each bushfire warning level, please see the Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development website.

PARK CLOSURES

Park closed in

WA POLICE

New agency information test

EXTRA INFORMATION

  • The incident was reported at (time) on (date).

  • The cause of the incident is unknown/accidental/suspicious or deliberately lit.

People are asked to report any suspicious behaviour to Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

SUPPORT INFORMATION

Emergency assistance is available for individuals or families to alleviate the personal hardship or distress arising as a direct result of a natural disaster. Contact the Department of Communities for further information OR Call the Disaster Line on 1800032965 for further information (when activated).

Important numbers

  • In a life threatening situation call 000.
  • If you are concerned about the location of family and friends in the area call the Red Cross State Inquiry Line on 1800 810 710 (if activated).

KEEP UP TO DATE

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.

During a power outage, your home phone, computer or other electronic devices connected to the NBN will not work. Include a battery powered radio in your emergency kit.


Updates will be issued every hour unless the situation changes.


END
DFES Media and Corporate Communications on 9395 9543

Road closures

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This is a new alert - SM Test.
Issued 1 May 2024 2:04 PM.
Earthquake Alert Take care after earthquake in COTTESLOE in the TOWN OF COTTESLOE

Geoscience Australia has advised that a magnitude 6.5 earthquake occurred 7688 kilometres from Location A on (02-05-2024 at 14:00

WHAT TO DO

During aftershocks:

  • DROP to the ground;
  • Take COVER under a sturdy table or other heavy furniture. If there is nothing to get under, cover your face and head with your arms and crouch alongside a bench or near an inside wall;
  • HOLD ON until the shaking stops.
  • If you are inside, stay inside and DROP, COVER and HOLD ON.
  • If you are outside, stay outside and move away from buildings.
  • Be careful of damaged buildings and falling debris.
  • Do not approach fallen power lines, they are dangerous and should always be treated as live.
  • Do not use lifts.
  • Do not use matches or cigarette lighters in case of gas leaks.
  • Check to see if your neighbours are safe.

If your home or property has been damaged, when it is safe to do so: (DELETE IF NO DAMAGE REPORTED)

  • Turn off electricity, gas and water.
  • Use a torch when entering a building. Never use matches, cigarette lighters or naked flames in case of gas leaks.
  • Check welfare of pets and animals.
  • Assess your home and property for damage, take photographs as soon as possible and contact your insurance company to organise repairs.
  • Start cleaning up around your home. Stack loose material clear of water meters, valves and power lines.
  • Wear safe clothing and footwear to protect yourself from injury by broken objects.
  • Clean up potentially harmful materials or medicines which may have spilled.
  • Be alert for dangerous tides (coastal areas only).
  • Be alert for tsunamis (coastal areas only).

Test for Safest Route for Earthquake Alert

Earthquake Final Alert FREMANTLE in the CITY OF FREMANTLE recovers after earthquake

Geoscience Australia has advised that a magnitude 7.1 earthquake occurred 8k kilometres from A on 30th April 2024 at 9am.

WHAT TO DO

  • Take care on the roads and drive with caution.
  • Be careful of damaged buildings and falling debris.
  • If your home has been damaged you should contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.

Test for safest route Earthquake final alert

Earthquake

COTTESLOE, TOWN OF COTTESLOE
  • Reported near COTTESLOE, WESTERN AUSTRALIA, AUSTRALIA, in COTTESLOE.
Earthquake details

The Joint Australian Tsunami Warning Centre have confirmed that there is NO TSUNAMI THREAT TO THE AUSTRALIAN MAINLAND, ISLANDS OR TERRITORIES from this earthquake or aftershocks.

Free Text for Earthquake details

Road closures

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and emergency services personnel working on site.

A number of roads have been closed including:

  • Road A

  • Road B

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.

  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.

  • Text Free Text

What Emergency Services are doing
  • DFES is monitoring the situation.
  • 10 State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers from 7 units are checking the status of utilities.
  • State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers have been supported by Fire and Rescue Service.

The Urban Search and Rescue (USAR) taskforce has been mobilised to search for trapped people OR help those trapped. DFES has requested additional search and rescue equipment and resources from interstate and overseas agencies.

(OR)

A local recovery committee has been established by (Shire/City), chaired by (name).

Free Text for other Assistance

(details eg: Rescuing trapped people / Treating injured people / Sheltering those left homeless / Assessing the damage / Controlling any fires / Stabilising essential buildings and structures if necessary / Clearing debris from essential facilities / Restoring lifeline services including water, power, gas, telephones, roads, rail)

Free Text for Other work by ES

Health

A number of hospitals have been damaged including (hospitals). The majority of elective surgery has been cancelled today.

The Department of Health is warning people to avoid contact with water in (area) rivers and at beaches near stormwater outlets due to contaminants being washed into these waters after yesterday's storm.

Parts of the (river name) River/s are experiencing (details eg: heavy inflows of contaminated stormwater, including a number of sewage overflows).

Recreational activities such as swimming, wading, fishing and canoeing should be avoided in these waterways for at least (details eg: a week).

Free Text for Health

Power

Western Power has advised parts of (location) are without power. This includes:

  • (details eg: list of streets / areas)

For further details visit www.westernpower.com.au.

Free Text Power

Water

The Water Corporation has advised that parts of (Location) are without water. This includes:

  • (details eg: list of streets / areas)

For further details visit www.watercorporation.com.au.

Free Text Water

Phone

Telstra has advised landline phones and mobile networks (where) have been (temporarily) disrupted due to (details eg: damage / congestion).

Affected customers should call the faults line on 13 22 03. If you are not a Telstra customer contact your service provider for help.

Free Text Phone

School

The Department of Education has advised a number of schools will remain closed including (schools). For more information contact your school directly or visit the Department of Education.

Free Text School

Insurance

If you have concerns regarding your insurance coverage contact the Insurance Council of Australia on 1300 728 228. This number is not to be used for claims.

Free Text Insurance

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Health.
This is a new alert.
Issued 3 May 2024 10:15 AM.
Heatwave Emergency Warning SHELTER INDOORS NOW for people in SOUTH BOULDER, LAKEWOOD, YILKARI, FEYSVILLE, KARRAMINDIE, KAMBALDA WEST and KAMBALDA EAST in the SHIRE OF COOLGARDIE and CITY OF KALGOORLIE-BOULDER
  • A Heatwave is affecting this area now.
  • You are in danger and seek or take shelter immediately from extreme heat.

WHAT TO DO

  • Stay indoors or in the shadiest place you can find.
  • Avoid exercise and strenuous or outdoor work.
  • If you must go out, wear a hat and sunscreen and take sufficient water with you.
  • Drink water frequently unless your doctor normally limits your fluids.
  • Never leave a person or pet in a car.
  • Check in regularly with elderly neighbours and other vulnerable people and help them stay cool.
  • Provide shelter and plenty of cool water for pets and other animals.
  • If available, use fans or air-conditioners to keep cool.
  • Do not travel unless essential.
Heatwave Watch and Act SHELTER INDOORS NOW for people in COOLGARDIE and KAMBALDA in the SHIRE OF COOLGARDIE and THE CITY OF KALGOORLIE BOULDER

A heatwave is affecting this area from (details eg: tomorrow / specific date).

WHAT TO DO

  • Avoid exercise and outdoor work in the hottest part of the day.
  • If you must go out, wear a hat and sunscreen and take sufficient water with you.
  • Take shelter in a cool place.
  • If available, use fans or air-conditioners to keep cool.
  • Drink water frequently unless your doctor normally limits your fluids.
  • Never leave a person or pet in a vehicle.
  • Check in regularly with elderly neighbours and other vulnerable people.
  • Provide shelter and plenty of cool water for pets and other animals.
  • Avoid travelling in the hottest part of the day where possible.
Heatwave Advice SHELTER INDOORS NOW for people in KALGOORLIE in the CITY OF KALGOORLIE-BOULDER

  • A heatwave is likely to affect this area in the next (number) days.

  • Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and prepare now for a heatwave that may affect your area.

WHAT TO DO

  • Plan outdoor and strenuous activities for days and times forecast to be coolest.
  • Stock up on bottled water if possible.
  • Get a battery powered radio with working batteries.
  • Charge mobile devices in the event there is a power outage.
  • Tell elderly neighbours and other vulnerable people about the hot weather coming.
  • Make sure you have shelter ready and water for pets and other animals.
  • If you have an air-conditioner check it is working.
Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at Nando's Kalgoorlie, 72 Boulder Rd, Kalgoorlie 6430, Australia
  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at (details eg: address and directions if required).
  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.
  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.
  • OPTIONAL: If this is not possible, please still proceed to the evacuation centre with your pets and await further advice.

Safest route

If you live in (area) leave via (directions) towards (landmark).

School Closure

Kalgoorlie Senior Highschool closed

Extra information

The Bureau of Meteorology are forecasting an (level) heatwave to impact (areas) in (number) days and could last until (date).

Heatwaves are dangerous. Take extra care to prevent heat stress and heat stroke. In extreme circumstances you could be hospitalised or die.

Heatwaves can affect:

  • Babies and young children
  • Older children and teenagers
  • Pregnant women
  • Older people
  • People with existing physical/mental health conditions or on certain medications
  • People that exercise in the heat
Support information

If you feel unwell

  • Call HealthDirect on 1800 022 222.
  • See your GP or Health Clinic.
  • For severe or life-threatening symptoms call 000 for an ambulance.

Further support

  • For more information on heatwaves and how you can plan ahead for the heat visit Healthy WA.
  • Visit Health Direct How To Handle Heatwave.
  • For information on working in the heat visit Working Safely in Hot Conditions.
  • For the latest heatwave forecast visit Bureau of Meteorology.
Accessibility
  • Translated heatwave resources are available on the Healthy WA Translated Fact Sheets
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677
Keep up to date

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.

During a power outage, your home phone, computer or other electronic devices connected to the NBN will not work. Include a battery powered radio in your emergency kit.


No further updates will be issued.

The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This is a new alert.
Issued 1 May 2024 3:23 PM.
Storm Get Ready in parts of the Midwest Gascoyne

If you live in parts of the Midwest Gascoyne you need to get ready now for the thunderstorms coming later today.

Locations affected include Kalbarri and Geraldton.

The storm will arrive early tomorrow morning.

WHAT TO DO

Hazmat General Warning Fuel spill in POSTANS, MEDINA and KWINANA BEACH in the CITY OF KWINANA

There is a Fuel spill on Kwinana Beach, Western Australia near the intersection of Anketell Road and Rockingham Road in the CITY OF KWINANA.

  • A fuel truck has rolled on Rockingham Road causing it to spill its load of fuel.

  • There is a Fuel spill on Rockingham Road near the intersection of Anketell Road in the CITY OF KWINANA.

WHAT TO DO

  • As a precautionary measure, people in the area should remain inside, out of the smoke or fumes, with doors and windows closed. Air conditioners should also be switched off.
  • People should stay away from the area. If you are already in the area take advice from emergency services personnel.
  • People with medical concerns should contact their local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.
Facility or Park Closure Facility for Perth Motorplex in KWINANA BEACH in the CITY OF KWINANA

The Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES) has issued a facility closure at Perth Motorplex, 1610 Rockingham Rd, Perth 6167, Australia due to a fuel spill.

WHAT TO DO

  • People are urged to avoid the area, follow the advice of Parks and Wildlife Service staff and observe signage.
  • People already in the area should leave for a safer place.
  • For more information, contact your local Parks and Wildlife Service office.

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This alert has been downgraded to Watch and Act.
Issued 2 May 2024 5:51 PM.
Bushfire Watch and Act for parts of WEST BEACH, SINCLAIR and PINK LAKE in the SHIRE OF ESPERANCE

Bushfire WATCH AND ACT is in place for people in an area bound by Thompson Road, Synnot Street, Jones Street, Twilight Beach Road and Connolly Street in parts of WEST BEACH, SINCLAIR and PINK LAKE in the SHIRE OF ESPERANCE.

  • The alert level for this fire has been upgraded as fire behaviour is escalating.
  • There is a possible threat to lives and homes as a fire is burning in the area and conditions are changing.
  • The fire started near the intersection of [STREET_NAME] and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in WEST BEACH, SINCLAIR and PINK LAKE.

WHAT TO DO

  • If you are not prepared or you plan to leave, leave now if the way is clear.
  • If you are well prepared and plan to actively defend your home, make final preparations now.
  • If you plan to stay and actively defend, do not rely on mains water pressure as it may be affected. You need to have access to an independent water supply, and start patrolling your property to put out spot fires.
  • Keep doors and windows closed and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.
  • If you are not at home, do not try to return as conditions in the area could be very dangerous.
Bushfire Advice for parts of WEST BEACH, SINCLAIR and PINK LAKE in the SHIRE OF ESPERANCE

Bushfire ADVICE is in place for people in an area bound by Thompson Road, Synnot Street, Jones Street, Twilight Beach Road and Connolly Street in parts of WEST BEACH, SINCLAIR and PINK LAKE in the SHIRE OF ESPERANCE.

  • There is a lot of smoke in the area.
  • Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date in case the situation changes.
  • The fire started near the intersection of [STREET_NAME] and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in SINCLAIR, WEST BEACH, NULSEN and PINK LAKE.

WHAT TO DO

  • Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.
  • Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.
  • Close all doors and windows, and turn off evaporative air conditioners but keep water running through the system if possible.
  • Read through your bushfire survival plan.
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation gets worse. You can make a plan by visiting My Bushfire Plan.

If driving:

  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions. If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.
  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.
Bushfire All Clear for parts of SINCLAIR, WEST BEACH, NULSEN and PINK LAKE in the SHIRE OF ESPERANCE

Bushfire ALL CLEAR is in place for people in an area bound by Thomson Road, Connolly Street, Pink Lake Road and Johns Street in parts of SINCLAIR, WEST BEACH, NULSEN and PINK LAKE in the SHIRE OF ESPERANCE.

  • The danger has passed but you need to remain vigilant in case the situation changes.

WHAT TO DO

  • Drive slowly and with caution due to smoke and emergency services personnel working in the area.
Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at Loose Goose Restaurant in Esperance.

  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at Loose Goose Restaurant, 9A Andrew St, Esperance 6450, Australia.

  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.

  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.

  • If this is not possible, please still proceed to the evacuation centre with your pets and await further advice.

Safest route

People south of Thomspon Road it is too late to leave. People norht of Thompson Road should should leave in a northerly direction, if safe to do so.

Bushfire

WEST BEACH, SHIRE OF ESPERANCE
  • Time reported: 3:14 PM, Tuesday, April 30, 2024.
  • Last updated: 1:09 PM, Wednesday, May 1, 2024.
  • Response: Responding.
  • Reported near CONNOLLY ST, in WEST BEACH.
Bushfire behaviour
Road closures

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and emergency services personnel working on site.

A number of roads have been closed including:

  • Thompson Street

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.

  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.

Restricted Access Permits
  • Residents and business owners impacted by the fire can apply for a restricted access permit to enter designated areas for a specific time and purpose.
  • A restricted access permit issuing unit has been established at (location). Please bring along valid identity documents including a driver's licence or passport, and proof of the affected address.
  • Due to the ever changing conditions, the issuing of restricted access permits may temporarily stop and your patience is appreciated.
  • For more information about restricted access permits visit the Restricted Access Permits section of the DFES website or click here
What firefighters are doing
  • Firefighters are actively fighting the fire.
  • Aerial support has been sent to assist ground crews.
Drones and aerial support

Never fly a drone, model aircraft or multirotor near bushfires. Doing so poses a major safety risk to firefighting personnel in the air and on the ground, and forces aircraft to be grounded or redirected, hindering firefighting efforts.

Power

Western Power has advised parts of (location) are without power. This includes:

  • Several streets in the area.

For further details visit www.westernpower.com.au.

Register.Find.Unite

Register with Register.Find.Reunite to let your family and loved ones know you're OK, where you are located and to enquire about a loved one’s whereabouts. You can register from any computer or mobile device or in person at a temporary evacuation centre.

Animal Welfare

Owners or carers of livestock, pets and companion animals should activate their own animal welfare plan. During a bushfire take advice from Local Government Authorities to protect the lives of your animals while keeping yourself safe.

For more information on actions to take for each bushfire warning level, please see the Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development website.

Extra information

  • The incident was reported at 1:02 PM on 2 May 2024.

Keep up to date

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.

During a power outage, your home phone, computer or other electronic devices connected to the NBN will not work. Include a battery powered radio in your emergency kit.


The next update will be provided by 4pm today unless the situation changes.

The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This is a new alert - Suvi.
Issued 1 May 2024 3:19 PM.
Earthquake Alert Take care after earthquake in SORRENTO in the CITY OF JOONDALUP

Geoscience Australia has advised that a magnitude (number) earthquake occurred (number) kilometres from (location) on (date) at (time).

WHAT TO DO

During aftershocks:

  • DROP to the ground;
  • Take COVER under a sturdy table or other heavy furniture. If there is nothing to get under, cover your face and head with your arms and crouch alongside a bench or near an inside wall;
  • HOLD ON until the shaking stops.
  • If you are inside, stay inside and DROP, COVER and HOLD ON.
  • If you are outside, stay outside and move away from buildings.
  • Be careful of damaged buildings and falling debris.
  • Do not approach fallen power lines, they are dangerous and should always be treated as live.
  • Do not use lifts.
  • Do not use matches or cigarette lighters in case of gas leaks.
  • Check to see if your neighbours are safe.

If your home or property has been damaged, when it is safe to do so: (DELETE IF NO DAMAGE REPORTED)

  • Turn off electricity, gas and water.
  • Use a torch when entering a building. Never use matches, cigarette lighters or naked flames in case of gas leaks.
  • Check welfare of pets and animals.
  • Assess your home and property for damage, take photographs as soon as possible and contact your insurance company to organise repairs.
  • Start cleaning up around your home. Stack loose material clear of water meters, valves and power lines.
  • Wear safe clothing and footwear to protect yourself from injury by broken objects.
  • Clean up potentially harmful materials or medicines which may have spilled.
Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at (details eg: location / centre)
  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at (details eg: address and directions if required).
  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.
  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.
  • OPTIONAL: If this is not possible, please still proceed to the evacuation centre with your pets and await further advice.

Safest route

If you live in (area) leave via (directions) towards (landmark).

Earthquake

SORRENTO, CITY OF JOONDALUP
  • Time reported: 2:21 PM, Tuesday, April 30, 2024.
  • Last updated: 1:46 PM, Wednesday, May 1, 2024.
  • Response: Responding.
  • Reported near PADBURY CIR, in SORRENTO.

The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
There is no change to the previous alert.
Issued 1 May 2024 3:33 PM.
Tsunami Land Warning for parts of the PERTH METROPOLITAN

  • A Tsunami LAND WARNING has been issued for people along the coast in or near PERTH OR between the (ocean) and (landmark).

  • There could be rapid and powerful flooding for people in low lying coastal areas when the tsunami impacts the coast.

  • The Tsunami may cause dangerous waves, rips and currents. This means it is not safe to swim or surf.

  • The Tsunami is expected to affect coastal areas near

WHAT TO DO

If you are at home in a low lying area

  • Leave now for a safe place at least 10 metres above sea level or one kilometre away from the water.
  • Take your emergency kit, including important papers, medication, keys, mobile phone and money with you. Only take what you can carry.
  • Walk to safety if possible. Avoid driving if you can.
  • Make sure everyone is wearing sturdy shoes.
  • If you cannot leave, take shelter on the upper level of a sturdy brick or concrete multi-story building.
  • If you are away from home, do not try to return.If you are at home, turn off electricity, gas and water and unplug all electrical appliances.

If you are in a coastal area

  • Get out of the water and move at least 10 metres above sea level or at least one kilometre inland.
  • If you are unable to move away from the water, seek shelter on the upper level of a brick or concrete multi-storey building.

If you are at sea

  • If your boat is in shallow water return to shore, secure your vessel and move away from the harbour or marina.
  • If you are out at sea, go to deeper water, at least 25 metres depth and stay there until the all clear is given.
Tsunami Marine Warning for parts of the PERTH METROPOLITAN

  • A Tsunami MARINE WARNING has been issued for people on beaches, harbours marines, rock platforms and coastal estuaries between NORTHBRIDGE and PERTH.

  • The Tsunami may cause dangerous waves, rips and currents in harbours, coastal estuaries and along beaches. This means it is not safe to swim or surf.

  • The Tsunami is expected to affect coastal areas near (areas).

WHAT TO DO

If you are in a coastal area

  • Get out of the water and move at least 10 metres above sea level or at least one kilometre inland.
  • If you are unable to move away from the water, seek shelter on the upper level of a brick or concrete multi-storey building.

If you are at sea

  • If your boat is in shallow water return to shore, secure your vessel and move away from the harbour or marina.
  • If you are out at sea, go to deeper water, at least 25 metres depth and stay there until the all clear is given.

if you are in the area leave for higher ground now

Tsunami Watch for parts of the METRO NORTH COASTAL

A Tsunami WATCH has been issued for people along the coast in or near WEST PERTH OR between the ocean) and roads).

WHAT TO DO

  • There is a possible tsunami threat. At this stage there have been no tsunami waves observed by the Joint Australian Tsunami Warning Centre that pose a threat however you need to remain alert in case the situation changes.
  • Decide now where you and your family will go if there is a tsunami.
  • Tell friends and family where you will go.
  • If you are at home, grab your emergency kit and medications, mobile phone and other essential supplies. Only pack what you can carry.
  • Make sure everyone is wearing sturdy shoes and suitable clothing.
  • Make sure your neighbours have received this warning.

If you are at sea

  • If your boat is in shallow water return to shore, secure your vessel and move away from the harbour or marina.
  • If you are out at sea, go to deeper water, at least 25 metres depth and stay there until the all clear is given.
Tsunami All Clear for parts of the PERTH METROPOLITAN

An ALL CLEAR advice has been issued for people in or near EAST PERTH.

WHAT TO DO

  • It is now safe to return home.
  • If returning, follow directions from emergency services and obey road closure signs.
  • Never drive into floodwaters of unknown depth and current.
  • Be careful of fallen power lines and trees, broken water and sewage pipes, loose roof sheeting and other material.
  • Do not walk, swim or play in floodwaters as they are dangerous.
  • Stay out of the water as unusual rips, tides and currents may occur for several hours

IF YOUR HOME HAS BEEN DAMAGED

  • Wear Sturdy Shoes
  • Stack loose material clear of water meters, valves and telephone lines.
  • Keep electricity and all appliances turned off until checked by an electrician.
  • Have gas appliances inspected and cleaned before use.
  • Never use matches, cigarette lighters or naked flames when entering a building in case flammable gas has leaked.
  • Take photographs of any damage and contact your insurance company as soon as you can.
  • If it is not safe to stay in your home, contact the Department of Communities Disaster Response Hotline on 1800 032 965.
Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at RAC Arena

  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at (details eg: address and directions if required).

  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.

  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.

  • OPTIONAL: If this is not possible, please still proceed to the evacuation centre with your pets and await further advice.

Safest route

If you live in (area) leave via (directions) towards (landmark).

  • No one will be allowed on site as it will not be safe.

  • Parents and carers are asked to keep their children home.

Tsunami details

  • was caused by (details eg: an/a undersea earthquake / earthquake / landslide / volcano eruption)> of magnitude (number)which occurred at (time) approximately (number)kilometres near (location).

  • the tsunami is expected to affect areas along the foreshore including beaches, marines and harbours.

ALERT LEVEL

  • A Tsunami LAND WARNING has been issued for people along the coast in or near PERTH OR between the (ocean) and (landmark).

  • There could be rapid and powerful flooding for people in low lying coastal areas when the tsunami impacts the coast.

  • The Tsunami may cause dangerous waves, rips and currents. This means it is not safe to swim or surf.

  • The Tsunami is expected to affect coastal areas near

WHAT TO DO

If you are at home in a low lying area

  • Leave now for a safe place at least 10 metres above sea level or one kilometre away from the water.
  • Take your emergency kit, including important papers, medication, keys, mobile phone and money with you. Only take what you can carry.
  • Walk to safety if possible. Avoid driving if you can.
  • Make sure everyone is wearing sturdy shoes.
  • If you cannot leave, take shelter on the upper level of a sturdy brick or concrete multi-story building.
  • If you are away from home, do not try to return.If you are at home, turn off electricity, gas and water and unplug all electrical appliances.

If you are in a coastal area

  • Get out of the water and move at least 10 metres above sea level or at least one kilometre inland.
  • If you are unable to move away from the water, seek shelter on the upper level of a brick or concrete multi-storey building.

If you are at sea

  • If your boat is in shallow water return to shore, secure your vessel and move away from the harbour or marina.
  • If you are out at sea, go to deeper water, at least 25 metres depth and stay there until the all clear is given.

Tsunami Marine Warning for parts of the PERTH METROPOLITAN

ALERT LEVEL

  • A Tsunami MARINE WARNING has been issued for people on beaches, harbours marines, rock platforms and coastal estuaries between NORTHBRIDGE and PERTH.

  • The Tsunami may cause dangerous waves, rips and currents in harbours, coastal estuaries and along beaches. This means it is not safe to swim or surf.

  • The Tsunami is expected to affect coastal areas near (areas).

WHAT TO DO

If you are in a coastal area

  • Get out of the water and move at least 10 metres above sea level or at least one kilometre inland.
  • If you are unable to move away from the water, seek shelter on the upper level of a brick or concrete multi-storey building.

If you are at sea

  • If your boat is in shallow water return to shore, secure your vessel and move away from the harbour or marina.
  • If you are out at sea, go to deeper water, at least 25 metres depth and stay there until the all clear is given.

if you are in the area leave for higher ground now

Tsunami Watch for parts of the METRO NORTH COASTAL

ALERT LEVEL

A Tsunami WATCH has been issued for people along the coast in or near WEST PERTH OR between the ocean) and roads).

WHAT TO DO

  • There is a possible tsunami threat. At this stage there have been no tsunami waves observed by the Joint Australian Tsunami Warning Centre that pose a threat however you need to remain alert in case the situation changes.
  • Decide now where you and your family will go if there is a tsunami.
  • Tell friends and family where you will go.
  • If you are at home, grab your emergency kit and medications, mobile phone and other essential supplies. Only pack what you can carry.
  • Make sure everyone is wearing sturdy shoes and suitable clothing.
  • Make sure your neighbours have received this warning.

If you are at sea

  • If your boat is in shallow water return to shore, secure your vessel and move away from the harbour or marina.
  • If you are out at sea, go to deeper water, at least 25 metres depth and stay there until the all clear is given.

Tsunami All Clear for parts of the PERTH METROPOLITAN

ALERT LEVEL

An ALL CLEAR advice has been issued for people in or near EAST PERTH.

WHAT TO DO

  • It is now safe to return home.
  • If returning, follow directions from emergency services and obey road closure signs.
  • Never drive into floodwaters of unknown depth and current.
  • Be careful of fallen power lines and trees, broken water and sewage pipes, loose roof sheeting and other material.
  • Do not walk, swim or play in floodwaters as they are dangerous.
  • Stay out of the water as unusual rips, tides and currents may occur for several hours

IF YOUR HOME HAS BEEN DAMAGED

  • Wear Sturdy Shoes
  • Stack loose material clear of water meters, valves and telephone lines.
  • Keep electricity and all appliances turned off until checked by an electrician.
  • Have gas appliances inspected and cleaned before use.
  • Never use matches, cigarette lighters or naked flames when entering a building in case flammable gas has leaked.
  • Take photographs of any damage and contact your insurance company as soon as you can.
  • If it is not safe to stay in your home, contact the Department of Communities Disaster Response Hotline on 1800 032 965.

EVACUATION CENTRE

Evacuation Centre open at RAC Arena

  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at (details eg: address and directions if required).

  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.

  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.

  • OPTIONAL: If this is not possible, please still proceed to the evacuation centre with your pets and await further advice.

Safest route

If you live in (area) leave via (directions) towards (landmark).

SCHOOL CLOSURE

Temporary School Closure for Mercedes College

  • Mercedes college will be closed on (date) due to (reason) and road closures.

  • No one will be allowed on site as it will not be safe.

  • Parents and carers are asked to keep their children home.

  • Further information will be provided when the situation changes.

TSUNAMI DETAILS

The Joint Australian Tsunami Warning Centre advises that the tsunami:

  • was caused by (details eg: an/a undersea earthquake / earthquake / landslide / volcano eruption)> of magnitude (number)which occurred at (time) approximately (number)kilometres near (location).

  • at this stage no tsunami waves have been detected that may threaten Western Australia.

  • the tsunami is expected to affect areas along the foreshore including beaches, marines and harbours.

  • the tsunami is expected to cause flooding in low lying coastal areas past beaches, dangerous waves and strong ocean currents

The Joint Australian Tsunami Warning Centre has advised that:

  • the tsunami warning has been cancelled.

  • the threat of a tsunami has now passed.

  • the main tsunami waves have now passed but unusual rips, tides and currents may continue.

  • there have been no tsunami waves observed by the Joint Australian Tsunami Warning Centre that pose a threat.

Tsunami could impact these locations at the following times:

  • Exmouth from (time)
  • Onslow from (time)
  • Carnarvon from (time)
  • Broome from (time)
  • Geraldton from (time)
  • Perth metropolitan area from (time)
  • Bunbury from (time)
  • Albany from (time)
  • Esperance from (time)

ROAD CLOSURES

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and emergency services personnel working on site.

A number of roads have been closed including:

  • Rockingham Road

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.
  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.

WHAT EMERGENCY SERVICES ARE DOING

  • DFES is monitoring the situation.
  • 20 State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers from 3 units are pumping out flood water.
  • They are being supported by Fire and Rescue Service.

DFES Incident Management Team and SES volunteers are/have been busy helping people in (location) by (details eg: assessing damage to buildings / rescuing trapped people / clearing debris)

The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES)

Issued: 1 May 2024 3:45 PM

A Total Fire Ban has been declared for 2 May 2024 for the local government districts listed below:

KIMBERLEY
SHIRE OF BROOME - All day



At these times you must not:

  • Light, maintain or use a fire in the open air
  • Carry out any activity that could start a fire


This includes:

  • Open fires for the purpose of cooking, camping or outdoor entertainment are not allowed including fire pits and bonfires.
  • Hot work such as metal work, grinding, welding, gas cutting is not allowed in the open air except for business and industry if regulatory conditions are met.
  • Off-road activity using a four-wheel drive, quad bike, motorcycle, bobcat or similar vehicle, except for agricultural purposes or by business and industry if regulatory conditions are met.


If a Harvest and Vehicle Movement Ban has been imposed by your local government, off-road activity for agriculture or business and industry including harvesting is banned. Exceptions are made for essential services.


For a list of activities that can or cannot be carried out during a Total Fire Ban and conditions visit dfes.wa.gov.au/totalfirebans or by telephoning the Total Fire Ban Information Line on 1800 709 355.


You could be fined up to $25,000 or jailed for 12 months or both if you breach a Total Fire Ban.


Current Total Fire Bans are also available by visiting www.emergency.wa.gov.au/#totalfirebans
Local Government Authority boundaries on Emergency WA are indicative only and do not represent the exact gazetted local government boundary.


END
Media Contact: DFES Media and Corporate Communications on 9395 9543.

Issued 2 May 2024 11:47 AM.
Smoke Alert Smoke Alert for eastern parts of ARMADALE in the CITY OF ARMADALE

  • A Smoke Alert has been issued for people in/travelling along Road and surrounding areas in ARMADALE in the CITY OF ARMADALE.

  • The smoke is the result of a bushfire burning in the area.

  • The smoke is expected to clear tomorrow.

WHAT TO DO

  • Shut doors and windows and turn off air-conditioners.
  • If driving through the area, turn on headlights and drive slowly. If you cannot see clearly, pull over to the left, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.
  • People with asthma and pre-existing respiratory or cardiovascular illnesses should follow their pre-prepared treatment plan.
  • If affected by smoke, contact your doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.

Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at Gwynne Park, 1 Townley St, Perth 6112

  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at Gwynne Park, 1 Townley St, Perth 6112.

  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.

  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.

  • If this is not possible, please still proceed to the evacuation centre with your pets and await further advice.

Safest route

Road closures

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and emergency services personnel working on site.

A number of roads have been closed including:

  • Albany Highway

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
blah blah.
Issued 2 May 2024 3:38 PM.
Storm Take Action Now in parts of the SOUTH WEST

If you live in (BoM district) you should take action and stay safe with (severe thunderstorms / weather) to come.

location loacation

WHAT TO DO

  • If outside find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams.
  • Close your curtains and blinds, and stay inside away from windows.
  • Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephones if there is lightning.
  • If there is flooding, create your own sandbags by using pillow cases filled with sand and place them around doorways to protect your home.
  • If boating, swimming or surfing leave the water.

If driving

  • Do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Slow down, turn your lights on and keep a safe distance from other drivers.
  • Be alert and watch for hazards on the road such as fallen powerlines and loose debris.
  • If it is raining heavily and you cannot see, pull over and park with your hazard lights on until the rain clears.
  • Take care in areas that have been flooded and be careful driving on gravel roads as surfaces will be slippery and muddy, and vehicles could become bogged.
Storm Get Ready in parts of the SOUTH WEST

If you live in (BoM district) you need to get ready now for the (severe thunderstorms / weather) coming [time].

blah

The storm will arrive tonight.

WHAT TO DO

  • Store or weigh down loose objects around your home like outdoor furniture that could be picked up and thrown by strong winds, causing damage or injury.
  • Ensure your emergency kit is complete including a battery operated radio, torch, spare batteries and first aid kit.
  • Ensure pets and animals are in a safe area.
  • Move vehicles under cover.
  • Boat owners should securely moor their boats.
  • Campers should find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams.
  • Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephones if there is lightning.
  • If you are away from home contact family or friends to prepare your property.
Storm Prepare in parts of the SOUTH WEST

If you live in (BoM district) you need to get ready for (severe thunderstorms / weather) coming [time].

blah

The storm will arrive tomorrow.

WHAT TO DO

  • Trim branches around your home to prevent them falling on your roof or car.
  • Clear gutters and downpipes so they do not overflow after heavy rain.
  • Store or weigh down loose objects around your home or work like outdoor furniture that could be picked up and thrown by strong winds, causing damage or injury.
  • Prepare an emergency kit with a battery operated radio, torch, spare batteries and first aid kit.
  • Organise an emergency plan, including a plan to evacuate for your family and pets in case your home becomes flooded.
Storm Cancellation in parts of the SOUTH WEST

The [severe weather/thunderstorm] warning for the (BoM district) has been cancelled.

busso

WHAT TO DO

  • Keep away from flooded drains, rivers, streams and waterways.
  • Be careful of fallen trees, damaged buildings and debris.
  • Keep clear of fallen powerlines, they are dangerous and should always be treated as live.
  • Assess your home, car and property for damage.
  • Check to see if your neighbour needs help.
  • If damage has occurred, take photos and contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.
  • If your home has significant damage, like a badly damaged roof or flooding, call the SES on 132 500.

Storm

BUSSELTON, CITY OF BUSSELTON
  • Reported near BUSSELTON, WESTERN AUSTRALIA, AUSTRALIA, in BUSSELTON.
Road closures

Some roads may be closed.

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.
  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.
What Emergency Services are doing
  • DFES is monitoring the situation.
Keep up to date

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.

During a power outage, your home phone, computer or other electronic devices connected to the NBN will not work. Include a battery powered radio in your emergency kit.
