The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
Boom boom.
Issued 2 May 2024 8:15 AM.
Earthquake Alert Take care after earthquake in MARGARET RIVER and BRAMLEY in the SHIRE OF AUGUSTA MARGARET RIVER

Geoscience Australia has advised that a magnitude (number) earthquake occurred (number) kilometres from (location) on (date) at (time).

WHAT TO DO

During aftershocks:

  • DROP to the ground;
  • Take COVER under a sturdy table or other heavy furniture. If there is nothing to get under, cover your face and head with your arms and crouch alongside a bench or near an inside wall;
  • HOLD ON until the shaking stops.
  • If you are inside, stay inside and DROP, COVER and HOLD ON.
  • If you are outside, stay outside and move away from buildings.
  • Be careful of damaged buildings and falling debris.
  • Do not approach fallen power lines, they are dangerous and should always be treated as live.
  • Do not use lifts.
  • Do not use matches or cigarette lighters in case of gas leaks.
  • Check to see if your neighbours are safe.

If your home or property has been damaged, when it is safe to do so: (DELETE IF NO DAMAGE REPORTED)

  • Turn off electricity, gas and water.
  • Use a torch when entering a building. Never use matches, cigarette lighters or naked flames in case of gas leaks.
  • Check welfare of pets and animals.
  • Assess your home and property for damage, take photographs as soon as possible and contact your insurance company to organise repairs.
  • Start cleaning up around your home. Stack loose material clear of water meters, valves and power lines.
  • Wear safe clothing and footwear to protect yourself from injury by broken objects.
  • Clean up potentially harmful materials or medicines which may have spilled.
Earthquake Final Alert BRAMLEY and MARGARET RIVER in the SHIRE OF AUGUSTA MARGARET RIVER recovers after earthquake

Geoscience Australia has advised that a magnitude (number) earthquake occurred (number) kilometres from (location) on (date) at (time).

WHAT TO DO

  • Take care on the roads and drive with caution.
  • Be careful of damaged buildings and falling debris.
  • If your home has been damaged you should contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.

Earthquake

MARGARET RIVER, SHIRE OF AUGUSTA MARGARET RIVER
  • Reported near MARGARET RIVER, WESTERN AUSTRALIA, AUSTRALIA, in MARGARET RIVER.
Earthquake details

The Joint Australian Tsunami Warning Centre have confirmed that there is NO TSUNAMI THREAT TO THE AUSTRALIAN MAINLAND, ISLANDS OR TERRITORIES from this earthquake or aftershocks.

Road closures

Some roads may be closed.

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.

WHAT TO DO

  • Leave now and go immediately to a safer place. This may be to family and friends who live away from the area, or to your closest temporary evacuation centre.
  • Take your emergency kit with you. This includes clothes, valuables, important documents (like identification, passports, insurance papers), medicines, cash, mobile phone and charger, canned food and water in waterproof bags.
  • If it is safe to do so, turn off electricity, gas and water.
  • Lock your doors and windows.
  • Decide how you will get to your safe place. If you come to a flooded road, turn around and go another way. Do not drive through flood water.
  • Never walk, swim, boat, ride or play in floodwaters as they are dangerous.
  • Help others if you can.
  • Make sure your neighbours and those in the area have received this warning.
Flood Take Action Now (Red) Flooding is (occurring) in LEEUWIN and AUGUSTA in parts of the [DFES_REGIONS]

People in LEEUWIN and AUGUSTA in the (BoM catchment) need to take action now as (details eg: moderate / major) flooding is occurring.

  • (if relevant: Flooding has cut off evacuation routes - it is now too dangerous to leave).
  • (if relevant: Water will be fast flowing and levels will rise quickly).
  • (if relevant: If your life is in immediate danger or you are trapped by floodwater, call Triple Zero (000)).
  • (if relevant: Emergency services may not be able to come to your home so you need to get up as high as you can to survive).

WHAT TO DO

  • Stay where you are and get up as high as you safely can. This could be upstairs or on the roof.
  • If you are outside, go to a safe place, indoors and on high ground.
  • If you cannot shelter inside, get to higher ground away from trees. Trees can fall down when the ground is very wet.
  • Stay inside and watch for rising flood water.
  • If floodwater comes inside, move to a higher point like the kitchen bench or table and call Triple Zero (000).
  • Do not expect emergency services to come to your door.
  • Move away from creeks and rivers.
  • Never walk, swim, boat, ride or play in floodwaters as they are dangerous.
  • Do not go near rivers, creeks, storm drains and pipes, ditches and ravines, as they are dangerous.
  • Have your emergency kit near you.
  • To help protect you from debris in the water and mosquito-borne risks, make sure everyone in your family is wearing strong shoes and suitable long, loose fitting clothing.
  • If it is safe to do so, help other people who are with you and warn friends, family and neighbours in the area.
  • Follow directions from emergency services personnel.
  • If it is safe to do so, disconnect power, water and gas supplies.
  • Lift important things like furniture, clothing and valuables on to beds, tables and into your roof space if possible.
  • Secure loose objects and outdoor equipment.
  • If you left the area, do not return until you are told by emergency services that it is safe to go back.

WHAT TO DO

  • Prepare to move cars, equipment, livestock and pets early so they are not caught in floodwaters.
  • Prepare an emergency kit including enough canned food and water to last for five to seven days, as well as clothing, important documents such as identification and insurance papers, medication, cash and a battery-operated radio to listen to warnings.
  • Fill your vehicle's fuel tank.
  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to evacuate.
  • Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters, as they are dangerous.
  • Do not park or camp adjacent to rivers.
  • Find out more about how to get ready for a flood at the DFES website click here.

If driving:

  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.

  • Carry extra food and water when travelling in case of long delays at crossings.
Flood Take Care (Cancellation) for flooding in parts of LOWER SOUTH WEST

TAKE CARE for flooding is in place for people in (BoM catchment). This includes people in AUGUSTA in the SHIRE OF AUGUSTA MARGARET RIVER.

WHAT TO DO

  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to act.

  • If you need to go outside be careful of fallen power lines or trees, broken water and sewerage lines, loose roof sheeting and other materials.

  • Do not turn on power or gas equipment until they have been professionally tested. If water went above power points have the house checked by an electrician before turning the power back on.

  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as you can.

  • Use a torch when entering a building, never use matches or cigarette lighters as they could start a fire if there is a gas leak.

  • To protect you from debris and mosquito-borne risks, wear long sleeved clothing and closed-in shoes.

  • Check to see if your friends and neighbours need help.

  • If you left the area, do not return until you are told by emergency services that it is safe to go home.

  • Never walk, swim, boat or play in floodwaters as they are dangerous.

If driving:

  • Floodways and river levels may rise (rapidly) and damage roads and bridges so be careful at crossings.

  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current. Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged.

WHAT TO DO

During an outage:

  • Unplug electrical appliances.
  • Switch off air conditioners.
  • Keep useful phone numbers in a safe place including SES 132 500 and your electricity provider.
  • Keep up to date on your mobile phone or radio.

If you come across fallen power lines:

  • Stay eight metres away and Make The Safe Call to Western Power on the emergency 24/7 number 13 13 51 so that emergency response crews can attend the hazard to make the area safe.
  • Have an emergency kit ready containing a waterproof torch, first-aid kit, non-perishable food, water, required medication and a battery-powered radio with spare batteries.

  • Shut doors and windows and turn off air-conditioners.

A POWER OUTAGE is impacting a large number of customers in MANJIMUP in the SHIRE OF MANJIMUP.

During an outage:

  • Unplug electrical appliances.
  • Switch off air conditioners.

  • Every person 12 years or over living in Western Australia must wear a face covering when they leave home. Information on this can be found here.

Human Pandemic

NORTHCLIFFE, SHIRE OF MANJIMUP
  • Reported near NORTHCLIFFE FOREST PARK BED & BREAKFAST, WHEATLEY COAST RD, NORTHCLIFFE 6262, AUSTRALIA, in NORTHCLIFFE.
Extra information

How you can keep yourself, your family and the community safe

  • Practise good hygiene (e.g. wash your hands often and cover coughs and sneezes).
  • Maintain physical distancing, keep at least 1.5 metres (or two big steps) away from others.
  • If you are sick, stay home. Do not go to work and get tested at a nearby testing location.
  • Download the COVIDSafe app.

If you feel unwell or have any of the symptoms of COVID-19

  • Get tested as soon as possible.
  • Self-isolate at home until you receive your test results.
  • Stay at home. Do not go to work, school or shopping.

Testing for COVID-19

  • Anyone in WA can be assessed for a COVID-19 test if they have any of the following:
  • A fever of 37.5 degrees or above.
  • A documented history of fever in the last few days.
  • An acute respiratory infection (e.g. shortness of breath, cough, sore throat).
  • Loss of smell and taste.

Nine COVID clinics are now operational, including at most major Perth hospitals, as well as in Bunbury and Broome. In other regions, please attend a public hospital, health service or remote health clinic. Please call ahead. Testing is also available through some private pathology clinics with GP referral.

For more information on testing and to find a location, visit www.healthywa.wa.gov.au/coronavirus.

Support information

For more information about COVID-19

  • For more information on COVID-19 visit the HealthyWA website.
  • Call the COVID-19 information hotline: 13 COVID (13 26 843).
  • Visit www.wa.gov.au/covid19.
  • View Western Australia’s daily COVID-19 statistics on the Department of Health website.
Accessibility

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This is a new alert.
Issued 2 May 2024 1:54 PM.
Earthquake Alert Take care after earthquake in BRUCE ROCK in the SHIRE OF BRUCE ROCK

Geoscience Australia has advised that a magnitude (number) earthquake occurred (number) kilometres from (location) on (date) at (time).

WHAT TO DO

During aftershocks:

  • DROP to the ground;
  • Take COVER under a sturdy table or other heavy furniture. If there is nothing to get under, cover your face and head with your arms and crouch alongside a bench or near an inside wall;
  • HOLD ON until the shaking stops.
  • If you are inside, stay inside and DROP, COVER and HOLD ON.
  • If you are outside, stay outside and move away from buildings.
  • Be careful of damaged buildings and falling debris.
  • Do not approach fallen power lines, they are dangerous and should always be treated as live.
  • Do not use lifts.
  • Do not use matches or cigarette lighters in case of gas leaks.
  • Check to see if your neighbours are safe.

If your home or property has been damaged, when it is safe to do so: (DELETE IF NO DAMAGE REPORTED)

  • Turn off electricity, gas and water.
  • Use a torch when entering a building. Never use matches, cigarette lighters or naked flames in case of gas leaks.
  • Check welfare of pets and animals.
  • Assess your home and property for damage, take photographs as soon as possible and contact your insurance company to organise repairs.
  • Start cleaning up around your home. Stack loose material clear of water meters, valves and power lines.
  • Wear safe clothing and footwear to protect yourself from injury by broken objects.
  • Clean up potentially harmful materials or medicines which may have spilled.
Earthquake Final Alert COLLIE in the SHIRE OF COLLIE recovers after earthquake

Geoscience Australia has advised that a magnitude (number) earthquake occurred (number) kilometres from (location) on (date) at (time).

WHAT TO DO

  • Take care on the roads and drive with caution.
  • Be careful of damaged buildings and falling debris.
  • If your home has been damaged you should contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.
Earthquake details

The Joint Australian Tsunami Warning Centre have confirmed that there is NO TSUNAMI THREAT TO THE AUSTRALIAN MAINLAND, ISLANDS OR TERRITORIES from this earthquake or aftershocks.

Road closures

Some roads may be closed.

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.
  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.
What Emergency Services are doing
  • DFES is monitoring the situation.

The Urban Search and Rescue (USAR) taskforce has been mobilised to search for trapped people OR help those trapped. DFES has requested additional search and rescue equipment and resources from interstate and overseas agencies.

(OR)

A local recovery committee has been established by (Shire/City), chaired by (name).

Health

A number of hospitals have been damaged including (hospitals). The majority of elective surgery has been cancelled today.

The Department of Health is warning people to avoid contact with water in (area) rivers and at beaches near stormwater outlets due to contaminants being washed into these waters after yesterday's storm.

Parts of the (river name) River/s are experiencing (details eg: heavy inflows of contaminated stormwater, including a number of sewage overflows).

Recreational activities such as swimming, wading, fishing and canoeing should be avoided in these waterways for at least (details eg: a week).

Power

Western Power has advised parts of (location) are without power. This includes:

  • (details eg: list of streets / areas)

For further details visit www.westernpower.com.au.

Water

The Water Corporation has advised that parts of (Location) are without water. This includes:

  • (details eg: list of streets / areas)

For further details visit www.watercorporation.com.au.

Phone

Telstra has advised landline phones and mobile networks (where) have been (temporarily) disrupted due to (details eg: damage / congestion).

Affected customers should call the faults line on 13 22 03. If you are not a Telstra customer contact your service provider for help.

School

The Department of Education has advised a number of schools will remain closed including (schools). For more information contact your school directly or visit the Department of Education.

Insurance

If you have concerns regarding your insurance coverage contact the Insurance Council of Australia on 1300 728 228. This number is not to be used for claims.

Register.Find.Unite

Register with Register.Find.Reunite to let your family and loved ones know you're OK, where you are located and to enquire about a loved one’s whereabouts. You can register from any computer or mobile device or in person at a temporary evacuation centre.

Test Agency Title

Test Agency Desc

Extra information

(number) local government areas were declared natural disaster zones as a result of the (widespread) damage.

Support information

Emergency assistance is available for individuals or families to alleviate the personal hardship or distress arising as a direct result of a natural disaster. Contact the Department of Communities for further information OR Call theDisaster Response Hotline on 1800032965 for further information (when activated).

Important numbers

  • For SES assistance call 132 500.
  • In a life threatening situation call 000.
  • For the latest weather information call 1300 659 210 or visit www.bom.gov.au.
  • For information about road conditions and closures contact local Police or Main Roads WA on 138 138.
  • If you are concerned about the location of family and friends in the area call the Red Cross State Inquiry Line on 1800 810 710 (if activated).
  • For advice on damaged asbestos contact your insurance company, local government environmental health office or Department of Health on 9388 4999 or after hours on 9328 0553 (in major incident).
Keep up to date

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This is a new alert.
Issued 3 May 2024 11:56 AM.
Bushfire Emergency Warning for the townsite of WICKEPIN in the SHIRE OF WICKEPIN

A Bushfire EMERGENCY WARNING is in place for people bounded by Williams-Kondinin Road to the south, Yarding Brook Road to the east, Hemley Road to the north and Wickepin and Wicjepin-Pingelly Road to the west in the SHIRE OF WICKEPIN.

  • You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive. There is a threat to lives and homes.
  • Homes in Wickepin are under threat by fire now.
  • The fire started near the intersection of [STREET_NAME] and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in WICKEPIN.

WHAT TO DO

  • If the way is clear, leave now for a safer place.

  • Do not wait and see, leaving at the last minute is deadly.

  • Close all doors and windows and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.

  • If you cannot leave, you need to get ready to shelter in your home.

  • Go to a room in your home away from the fire front and make sure you can easily escape.

  • Choose a room with two exits and water such as a kitchen or laundry.

  • If you are not at home, it's too dangerous to return.

Bushfire Watch and Act for eastern part of WICKEPIN in the SHIRE OF WICKEPIN

Bushfire WATCH AND ACT is in place for people bound by Russel Road to the north, Yarling Brook and Whites Road to the east, Wickepin-Kindinin Road to the south and Wickepin Road to the west in the SHIRE OF WICKEPIN.

  • There is a possible threat to lives and homes as a fire is approaching in the area and conditions are changing.
  • The fire started near the intersection of [STREET_NAME] and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in WICKEPIN.
  • It is burning towards (landmark).

WHAT TO DO

  • If you are not prepared or you plan to leave, leave now if the way is clear.
  • If you are well prepared and plan to actively defend your home, make final preparations now.
  • If you plan to stay and actively defend, do not rely on mains water pressure as it may be affected. You need to have access to an independent water supply, and start patrolling your property to put out spot fires.
  • Keep doors and windows closed and turn off evaporative air conditioners, but keep water running through the system if possible.
  • If you are not at home, do not try to return as conditions in the area could be very dangerous.
Bushfire Advice parts of MALYALLING and WICKEPIN in the SHIRE OF WICKEPIN

Bushfire ADVICE is in place for people in (area).

  • There is no threat to lives or homes.
  • There is a lot of smoke in the area.
  • Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date in case the situation changes.
  • The fire started near the intersection of [STREET_NAME] and [NEAREST_CROSS_STREET] in MALYALLING and WICKEPIN.
  • It is burning in an easterly direction.

WHAT TO DO

  • Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.
  • Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.
  • Close all doors and windows, and turn off evaporative air conditioners but keep water running through the system if possible.
  • Read through your bushfire survival plan.
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation gets worse. You can make a plan by visiting My Bushfire Plan.

If driving:

  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions. If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.
  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.
Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at Cuballing Tavern, 8 Alton St, Cuballing 6311,
  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at (details eg: address and directions if required).
  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.
  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.
  • OPTIONAL: If this is not possible, please still proceed to the evacuation centre with your pets and await further advice.

Safest route

If you live in the Emergency Warning area, leave via Wickepin-Williams Road in an easterly direction towards Cuballing.

Bushfire

WICKEPIN, SHIRE OF WICKEPIN
  • Time reported: 12:30 PM, Thursday, May 2, 2024.
  • Last updated: 12:52 PM, Thursday, May 2, 2024.
  • Reported near WICKEPIN, WESTERN AUSTRALIA, AUSTRALIA and WICKEPIN-PINGELLY ROAD, EAST PINGELLY WESTERN AUSTRALIA 6308, AUSTRALIA, in WICKEPIN.
Bushfire behaviour
Road closures

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and emergency services personnel working on site.

A number of roads have been closed including:

  • Fleay Road

  • Kerr Road

  • Aileen Road

  • Motorists are asked to avoid the area, reduce speed and drive carefully.
  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.
Drones and aerial support

Never fly a drone, model aircraft or multirotor near bushfires. Doing so poses a major safety risk to firefighting personnel in the air and on the ground, and forces aircraft to be grounded or redirected, hindering firefighting efforts.

Power

Western Power has advised parts of Wickepin are without power.

For further details visit www.westernpower.com.au.

Animal Welfare

Owners or carers of livestock, pets and companion animals should activate their own animal welfare plan. During a bushfire take advice from Local Government Authorities to protect the lives of your animals while keeping yourself safe.

For more information on actions to take for each bushfire warning level, please see the Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development website.

Extra information

  • The incident was reported at 9am on 5 May

  • The cause of the incident is suspicious or deliberately lit.

People are asked to report any suspicious behaviour to Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

Support information

Important numbers

  • In a life threatening situation call 000.

  • If you are concerned about the location of family and friends in the area call the Red Cross State Inquiry Line on 1800 810 710 (if activated).

Keep up to date

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.

During a power outage, your home phone, computer or other electronic devices connected to the NBN will not work. Include a battery powered radio in your emergency kit.


Updates will be issued every hour unless the situation changes.

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Health.
SLiP SLOP SLAP.
Issued 2 May 2024 3:08 PM.
Heatwave Emergency Warning SHELTER INDOORS NOW for people in SUBIACO, PERTH, NORTHBRIDGE, WEST PERTH, NORTH PERTH, LEEDERVILLE, WEST LEEDERVILLE, WEMBLEY, MOUNT HAWTHORN and MENORA in the CITY OF PERTH, CITY OF SUBIACO, CITY OF VINCENT, TOWN OF CAMBRIDGE and CITY OF STIRLING
  • A Heatwave is affecting this area now.
  • You are in danger and seek or take shelter immediately from extreme heat.

WHAT TO DO

  • Stay indoors or in the shadiest place you can find.
  • Avoid exercise and strenuous or outdoor work.
  • If you must go out, wear a hat and sunscreen and take sufficient water with you.
  • Drink water frequently unless your doctor normally limits your fluids.
  • Never leave a person or pet in a car.
  • Check in regularly with elderly neighbours and other vulnerable people and help them stay cool.
  • Provide shelter and plenty of cool water for pets and other animals.
  • If available, use fans or air-conditioners to keep cool.
  • Do not travel unless essential.
Heatwave Watch and Act SHELTER INDOORS NOW for people in YOKINE, COOLBINIA, MENORA, INGLEWOOD, DIANELLA, BEDFORD, MAYLANDS, MOUNT LAWLEY and NORTH PERTH in the CITY OF STIRLING, CITY OF BAYSWATER and CITY OF VINCENT

A heatwave is affecting this area from (details eg: tomorrow / specific date).

WHAT TO DO

  • Avoid exercise and outdoor work in the hottest part of the day.
  • If you must go out, wear a hat and sunscreen and take sufficient water with you.
  • Take shelter in a cool place.
  • If available, use fans or air-conditioners to keep cool.
  • Drink water frequently unless your doctor normally limits your fluids.
  • Never leave a person or pet in a vehicle.
  • Check in regularly with elderly neighbours and other vulnerable people.
  • Provide shelter and plenty of cool water for pets and other animals.
  • Avoid travelling in the hottest part of the day where possible.
Heatwave Advice TAKE SHELTER NOW for people in OSBORNE PARK, STIRLING, BALCATTA, TUART HILL, YOKINE, NOLLAMARA, DIANELLA and JOONDANNA in the CITY OF STIRLING
  • A heatwave is likely to affect this area in the next (number) days.
  • Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and prepare now for a heatwave that may affect your area.
  • (if downgrading: The alert level for this heatwave has been downgraded as the weather conditions are returning to normal)

WHAT TO DO

  • Plan outdoor and strenuous activities for days and times forecast to be coolest.
  • Stock up on bottled water if possible.
  • Get a battery powered radio with working batteries.
  • Charge mobile devices in the event there is a power outage.
  • Tell elderly neighbours and other vulnerable people about the hot weather coming.
  • Make sure you have shelter ready and water for pets and other animals.
  • If you have an air-conditioner check it is working.
Extra information

The Bureau of Meteorology are forecasting an (level) heatwave to impact (areas) in (number) days and could last until (date).

Heatwaves are dangerous. Take extra care to prevent heat stress and heat stroke. In extreme circumstances you could be hospitalised or die.

Heatwaves can affect:

  • Babies and young children
  • Older children and teenagers
  • Pregnant women
  • Older people
  • People with existing physical/mental health conditions or on certain medications
  • People that exercise in the heat
Support information

If you feel unwell

  • Call HealthDirect on 1800 022 222.
  • See your GP or Health Clinic.
  • For severe or life-threatening symptoms call 000 for an ambulance.

Further support

  • For more information on heatwaves and how you can plan ahead for the heat visit Healthy WA.
  • Visit Health Direct How To Handle Heatwave.
  • For information on working in the heat visit Working Safely in Hot Conditions.
  • For the latest heatwave forecast visit Bureau of Meteorology.
Accessibility

The following alert has been issued by the Department of Health.

SLiP SLOP SLAP.

Issued: 2 May 2024 3:08 PM

Heatwave Emergency Warning - SHELTER INDOORS NOW for people in SUBIACO, PERTH, NORTHBRIDGE, WEST PERTH, NORTH PERTH, LEEDERVILLE, WEST LEEDERVILLE, WEMBLEY, MOUNT HAWTHORN and MENORA in the CITY OF PERTH, CITY OF SUBIACO, CITY OF VINCENT, TOWN OF CAMBRIDGE and CITY OF STIRLING

ALERT LEVEL

  • A Heatwave is affecting this area now.
  • You are in danger and seek or take shelter immediately from extreme heat.

WHAT TO DO

  • Stay indoors or in the shadiest place you can find.
  • Avoid exercise and strenuous or outdoor work.
  • If you must go out, wear a hat and sunscreen and take sufficient water with you.
  • Drink water frequently unless your doctor normally limits your fluids.
  • Never leave a person or pet in a car.
  • Check in regularly with elderly neighbours and other vulnerable people and help them stay cool.
  • Provide shelter and plenty of cool water for pets and other animals.
  • If available, use fans or air-conditioners to keep cool.
  • Do not travel unless essential.

Heatwave Watch and Act - SHELTER INDOORS NOW for people in YOKINE, COOLBINIA, MENORA, INGLEWOOD, DIANELLA, BEDFORD, MAYLANDS, MOUNT LAWLEY and NORTH PERTH in the CITY OF STIRLING, CITY OF BAYSWATER and CITY OF VINCENT

ALERT LEVEL

A heatwave is affecting this area from (details eg: tomorrow / specific date).

WHAT TO DO

  • Avoid exercise and outdoor work in the hottest part of the day.
  • If you must go out, wear a hat and sunscreen and take sufficient water with you.
  • Take shelter in a cool place.
  • If available, use fans or air-conditioners to keep cool.
  • Drink water frequently unless your doctor normally limits your fluids.
  • Never leave a person or pet in a vehicle.
  • Check in regularly with elderly neighbours and other vulnerable people.

The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
Please note changes under What Emergency Services are Doing.
Issued 2 May 2024 4:26 PM.
Storm Cancellation in parts of the GREAT SOUTHERN and SOUTH WEST

The severe weather warning for the Lower West and Great Southern districts has been cancelled.

Severe thunderstorms with heavy rainfall are no longer occurring southeast of Mandurah.

WHAT TO DO

  • Keep away from flooded drains, rivers, streams and waterways.
  • Be careful of fallen trees, damaged buildings and debris.
  • Keep clear of fallen powerlines, they are dangerous and should always be treated as live.
  • Assess your home, car and property for damage.
  • Check to see if your neighbour needs help.
  • If damage has occurred, take photos and contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.
  • If your home has significant damage, like a badly damaged roof or flooding, call the SES on 132 500.
Evacuation Centre Evacuation Centre open at the Boddington Community Resource Centre

  • The Department of Communities has set up an evacuation centre at the Boddington Community Resource Centre

  • Please take any essential items such as medications and identification to the evacuation centre.

  • Pets (except recognised assistance animals) are not allowed inside evacuation centres for health and safety reasons, so you should make alternative arrangements for them.

  • If this is not possible, please still proceed to the evacuation centre with your pets and await further advice.

Safest route

Leave via Bannister Road in a northerly direction

Storm

BODDINGTON, SHIRE OF BODDINGTON
  • Time reported: 2:29 PM, Thursday, May 2, 2024.
  • Last updated: 12:00 AM, Thursday, May 2, 2024.
  • Reported near BODDINGTON, WESTERN AUSTRALIA, in BODDINGTON.
Road closures

Some roads may be closed. People need to make alternative travel arrangements.

  • Motorists are asked to reduce speed and drive carefully.

  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by visiting the Main Roads Travel Map, calling 138 138 or by contacting your Local Government Authority.

What Emergency Services are doing
  • DFES is monitoring the situation.
  • 30 State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers from 4 units are pumping out flood water.
  • State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers have been supported by career firefighters.

DFES is working closely with the WA Police Force

St John WA volunteers are treating injured people

Test

Test

Health

Elective surgery at Boddington Hospital has been cancelled today.

Power

Western Power has advised parts of Boddington are without power. This includes:

  • Hill Street

For further details visit www.westernpower.com.au.

Water

The Water Corporation has advised that parts of Boddington are without water. This includes:

  • Hill Street

For further details visit www.watercorporation.com.au.

Phone

Telstra has advised landline phones and mobile networks in Boddington have been temporarily disrupted.

Affected customers should call the faults line on 13 22 03. If you are not a Telstra customer contact your service provider for help.

School

The Department of Education has advised Boddington Primary will be closed today. For more information contact your school directly or visit the Department of Education.

Insurance

If you have concerns regarding your insurance coverage contact the Insurance Council of Australia on 1300 728 228.

Parks

Boddington National Park is closed.

Extra information

One local government area was declared natural disaster zones as a result of the widespread damage.

Support information

  • If it is safe to do so, please do what you can to help yourself before calling the SES for assistance.

  • If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the SES on 132 500.

  • In a life threatening situation call 000.

After a storm SES volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes or cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.

  • For the latest weather information call 1300 659 210 or visit www.bom.gov.au.

Keep up to date

Visit Emergency WA, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Facebook, listen to ABC Local Radio, 6PR, or news bulletins.


The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow unless the situation changes.

events.web-message:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES).
This is a new Alert.
Issued 2 May 2024 4:02 PM.
Storm Take Action Now in parts of the [DFES_REGIONS]

If you live in (BoM district) you should take action and stay safe with (severe thunderstorms / weather) to come.

WHAT TO DO

  • If outside find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams.
  • Close your curtains and blinds, and stay inside away from windows.
  • Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephones if there is lightning.
  • If there is flooding, create your own sandbags by using pillow cases filled with sand and place them around doorways to protect your home.
  • If boating, swimming or surfing leave the water.

If driving

  • Do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Slow down, turn your lights on and keep a safe distance from other drivers.
  • Be alert and watch for hazards on the road such as fallen powerlines and loose debris.
  • If it is raining heavily and you cannot see, pull over and park with your hazard lights on until the rain clears.
  • Take care in areas that have been flooded and be careful driving on gravel roads as surfaces will be slippery and muddy, and vehicles could become bogged.
Storm Prepare in parts of the METRO SOUTH COASTAL

If you live in (BoM district) you need to get ready for (severe thunderstorms / weather) coming [time].

The storm will arrive within 10 minutes.

WHAT TO DO

  • Trim branches around your home to prevent them falling on your roof or car.
  • Clear gutters and downpipes so they do not overflow after heavy rain.
  • Store or weigh down loose objects around your home or work like outdoor furniture that could be picked up and thrown by strong winds, causing damage or injury.
  • Prepare an emergency kit with a battery operated radio, torch, spare batteries and first aid kit.
  • Organise an emergency plan, including a plan to evacuate for your family and pets in case your home becomes flooded.

Storm

WANNANUP, FALCON, DAWESVILLE, BOUVARD, CLIFTON, HERRON, ERSKINE, HALLS HEAD, MANDURAH, CITY OF MANDURAH
